title: Advance Australian fashion
text:
Leading the pack is Zimmermann, she says, which has just opened its first Paris boutique – its fourth store in Europe following boutiques in Capri, Saint-Tropez and London – along with Toni Matičevski, Lee Mathews, the activewear label PE Nation (now stocked in Selfridges), and Camilla and Marc.

Camilla and Marc’s showroom this season is at the Ritz, that most famous of Parisian hotels where Coco Chanel once lived and Ernest Hemingway once drank – “liberating” the bar of German soldiers in 1944, according to hotel lore, by downing 51 dry martinis.

Camilla & Marc put on the Ritz. Laura Verheyde

On the racks in the Camilla & Marc suite hang examples of the brand’s signature tailoring with a twist, including a top and trousers set in burgundy leather and dresses in sunshine yellow and bold prints that have caught the eyes of buyers and press who have visited so far, says designer Camilla Freeman-Topper.

The best thing about showing in Paris, she says, is not just the opportunity to meet buyers and press from the around the world but the way it validates the brand's direction.

Design duo Marc Freeman and Camilla Freeman-Topper revel in the "melting pot" that is Paris. Laura Verheyde

For Freeman-Topper’s business partner (and brother) Marc Freeman, Paris during fashion week offers a unique “melting pot”. “You can have a meeting with someone from America in the morning and the Middle East in the afternoon. It’s diverse and wonderful to see an accord in what people are liking,” he says.

At one Camilla and Marc appointment a French buyer described Australians as “exotic”, says Freeman-Topper. A lost-in-translation description perhaps, but what stands is that Australia is “an incredible place with an incredible landscape, 24-plus hours away … and that’s desirable.”

Signature tailoring with a colourful accent from Camilla & Marc. Laura Verheyde

Behind a heavy blue door in the buzzing Marais district is the Catinella PR showroom, where Australian brands showing throughout the Paris season include cool-girl favourite Sir the Label, now stocked by Matchesfashion.com and the New York department store Bergdorf Goodman, and Christopher Esber, whose resort collection at Australia Fashion Week in May caused a buzz.

Advertisement

In Paris, he’s showing a continuation of this collection, based on the idea of feminine fragility coupled with masculine strength. There’s lovely fine French lace and sharp suiting, lots of greys and tonal shades peppered with buttery yellows.

“The idea of the collection for resort was going from office to the beach, so a lot of things had strings that represent bikinis and shirts that can unbutton,” says Esber, who celebrates 10 years in the fashion business this year. (“It doesn’t feel like I’ve had the business for 10 years, it goes so fast.”)

Christopher Esber does greys and neutrals his way. Laura Verheyde

For the designer, who says 90 per cent of his business comes from international markets with Asia the strongest, a showroom in Paris is the best time for face-to-face time with buyers. “Some designers don’t like being in showroom, but I like being here. It might not be the orthodox thing to do but I like the feedback from buyers,” he says.

He has travelled to Paris several times a year for the past six years, but it took a while to love the city of lights.

Today, Toni Matičevski's designs are stocked in 120 stores in 30 countries. Laura Verheyde

What he likes is the street culture. “Watching people, I know it’s a cliché, but I love looking at people on the street – what they’re wearing, how they’re wearing it. It’s great to do that anywhere, but particularly here. People really do a look, particularly the older demographic. You get surprised here, which is nice.”

Eight years ago we came to Paris with one appointment. But, you know, we had that one appointment and we were on a high. — Toni Matičevski

Over in a showroom in the chic 8th arrondissement, Toni Matičevski is surrounded by the beautiful, almost-couture like pieces of his latest collection. Like all of Matičevski’s work, it didn’t start with a particular reference point but a feeling. This time it was like when “you open a door and feel a soft breeze”, he says.

For Melbourne-based Matičevski, Paris is “almost like my second home”. He spends up to three weeks in the city four to six times a year, and lived in the 11th arrondissement for just over three years some 20 years back.

Advertisement

While Matičevski will be “out the back, fitting the models and greeting clients” during a typical showroom season, the process has taught him about resilience and the importance of staying true to your brand and your principles.

He’s seen enough fashion brands fail to know you have to, as he puts it, “be selfish in a good way”.

“Eight years ago [when the brand re-launched] we came to Paris with one appointment. But, you know, we had that one appointment and one order and we were on a high. We refused to budge on our terms and the way we work.”

Matičevski want to keep his brand "unpredictable in a positive way". Laura Verheyde

The brand is now stocked in 120 stores in 30 countries.

After 20 years in the business Matičevski says he feels lucky to “be able to develop my aesthetic in a way that is unique to me – and to sustain and grow that regardless of what else is happening and what is expected from me”.

And yet still his brand surprises people. “Most people come not knowing what to expect, which I find exciting. I want to keep it unpredictable in a positive way.”

Of Australia's fashion reputation, he likes it when people come expecting to see swimwear and find something else entirely.

“We still get questions [such as] how do they do this out of Australia? It’s kind of: ‘Who the f--k are these guys?’ ” he says. “I really like that.”
description: The relaxed sophistication of design from Down Under has struck a chord with international buyers at Paris fashion week.
